Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story:
I watched my younger brother tighten his helmet, his eyes shining with excitement as he eyed the steep, uneven ramp. He was determined to master a new skateboard trick, but I couldn’t shake the worry gnawing at me. As his sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, to keep him safe. I wanted to tell him to stop, to wait until the ramp was fixed, but I knew how much this meant to him.

At the same time, I felt the weight of my own expectations. As a Hindu, I was supposed to perform my daily rituals with devotion, but lately, I’d only managed to quietly repeat a short mantra under my breath, skipping the full puja. Guilt pressed on me from both sides—my brother’s hopeful glance, the memory of my mother’s gentle reminders about our faith. I stood there, torn, feeling the pressure of being a good sibling and a good Hindu, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left undone.
